componenttext: Good morning, my name is Regina, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Comerica Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  Ms. Darlene Persons, you maybe begin the conference

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Regina. Good morning, and welcome to Comerica's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. This Darlene Persons, Director of Investor Relations. I am here with our Chairman Ralph Babb; our Chief Financial Officer, Beth Acton; and Dale Greene
componenttext: Thank you, Regina. Good morning, and welcome to Comerica's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. This Darlene Persons, Director of Investor Relations. I am here with our Chairman Ralph Babb; our Chief Financial Officer, Beth Acton; and Dale Greene, our Chief Credit Officer. A copy of our earnings release, financial statements and supplemental information is available on the SEC's website, as well as on our website.Before we get started, I would like to remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements. And in that regard, you should be mindful of the risks and uncertainties that can cause future results to vary from expectations. I refer you to the Safe Harbor statement contained in the earnings release issued today, which I incorporate into this call, as well as our filings with the SEC. Also this conference call will reference non-GAAP financial measures and in that regard, I would direct you to the calculation of these measures within the earnings release and presentation. Now I'll turn the call over Ralph.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We saw many encouraging signs in the fourth quarter, including improved credit metrics, continued strong deposit growth, a slower pace of decline in loan demand and a notable increase in the net interest margin. These positive development co
componenttext: Good morning. We saw many encouraging signs in the fourth quarter, including improved credit metrics, continued strong deposit growth, a slower pace of decline in loan demand and a notable increase in the net interest margin. These positive development could lead us to believe our core fundamentals will continue to show improvement in 2010. We are pleased to see broad-based improvement in credit quality. Net credit-related charge-offs decreased $14 million in the fourth quarter, non-performing assets decreased $13 million and the provision for loan losses decreased $54 million. Non-accrual loans were charged down to 44% as of December 31, versus 41% at September 30.Our watch list loans were down $520 million. We believe these improved credit metrics are the result of our diligent management of credit throughout this economic cycle. With unemployment at 10%, business owners and managers, as well as consumers, remain cautious. This is reflected in the subdued loan demand and in our core deposits, which increased $935 million from the third quarter. However, our customers are conveying a more confident tone, and we are seeing more loans in the pipeline. New and renewed loan commitments totaled $9.8 billion in the fourth quarter. Combined with our strong capital levels and dedicated colleagues, we believe we are ideally positioned to develop new relationships and expand existing ones as the economy continues its recovery.Our net interest margin increased 26 basis points to 2.94% in the fourth quarter. Excluding excess liquidity, represented by average balances deposited with the Federal Reserve Bank, the net interest margin would have been 3.07%. We continue to focus on expense controls. Our workforce has been reduced by 8% from 2008, even as we added 10 new banking centers in 2009. Our capital position remains strong. Our Tier 1 Capital ratio is estimated to be 12.46% at December 31. In addition, the quality of our capital remained solid as evidenced by a tangible common equity ratio of 7.99%.With regard to the $2.25 billion in preferred stock, we still plan to redeem it at such time as feasible with careful consideration given to the economic environment. It remains a top-corporate priority. In summary, we believe the future is brighter and that current opportunities are ahead of us because of the many positive signs we have seen in the fourth quarter. These positive signs are reflected in the breadth of improvement we have seen in credit quality, as well as in our strong deposit growth, the less subdued loan demand and in our increasing net interest margin. Our customers are expressing more optimism, and we share that optimism with them as the economy continues its recovery. And now, I'll turn the call over to Beth and Dale who will discuss our fourth quarter results in more detail.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ralph. As I review our fourth quarter results, I will be referring to slides that we prepared that provide additional details on our earnings. Turning to Slide 3, we outlined the major components of our fourth quarter and full year results comp
componenttext: Thank you, Ralph. As I review our fourth quarter results, I will be referring to slides that we prepared that provide additional details on our earnings. Turning to Slide 3, we outlined the major components of our fourth quarter and full year results compared to prior periods. Today, we report our fourth quarter 2009 net loss of $29 million. After preferred dividends of $33 million, the net loss applicable to common stock was $62 million or $0.41 per diluted share.Slide 4 provides an overview of the financial results for the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter. Credit quality metrics improved consistent with our outlook. Non-performing assets declined $13 million, and the inflow to non-accruals slowed by $95 million to $266 million. Net credit-related charge-offs decreased to $225 million, and the provision declined to $257 million compared to $311 million in the third quarter. The net interest margin in the fourth quarter increased 26 basis points to 2.94%. Produced deposit rates, maturing of higher cost-time deposits and improved loan spreads, all contributed to the increase. The lower turn on excess liquidity had a 13 basis-point impact, which I'll describe in more detail in a minute.We had very strong deposit generation again, in the fourth quarter with core deposits increasing $935 million, including a $1.2 billion increase in non-interest-bearing deposits. Average earning assets decreased $3.6 billion, including a $2 billion decline in loan outstandings. Our customers continue to be cautious in the current economic environment. Average other earning assets, primarily Federal Reserve Bank deposits and investment securities declined $1.6 billion as average excess liquidity was reduced.Non-interest income decreased due to a $97 million decline in securities' gains consistent with our outlook. We continue to carefully control expenses. The fourth quarter results reflected a decrease in regular salaries and incentives, which were more than offset by an increase in severance expense, relating to a planned reduction of 300 full-time equivalent positions. Our workforce has been reduced by about 850 positions or 8% since December 2008. Full year 2009 non-interest expenses decreased 6% from 2008. Our capital position is strong and was further enhanced in the fourth quarter. But Tier 1 Capital ratio increased to an estimated 12.46% at December 31. In addition, the quality of our capital is solid as evidenced by our tangible common equity ratio of 7.99%. Turning to Slide 5, average loan outstandings declined at a slower pace in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter. Consistent with post-recessionary environments, we had low loan demand in all of our geographic markets, as customers continue to deleverage as they cautiously manage their businesses. Decreased average outstandings in the fourth quarter were noted in virtually every area with the largest declines in Middle-Market, Global Corporate Banking and Commercial Real Estate. Line utilization was 46.8% in the fourth quarter, down slightly from the third quarter.As shown on Slide 6, we had very strong core deposit growth again in the fourth quarter. We had  growth in Texas, Western and Florida markets and all commercial lines of business. Average core deposits increased $935 million, including a $1.2 billion increase in non-interest-bearing deposits. While deposit rates are significantly lower today, I'm pleased to say that today, we've retained the vast majority of the balances of maturing customer CDs, many of which were put on in late 2008 at rates over 3%. Deposit pricing conditions remained competitive in the fourth quarter, and we believe we have hit rate floors on a number of our products. However, we were able to selectively decrease rates and [indiscernible] deposit categories.As outlined on Slide 7, the net interest margin increased 26 basis points in the fourth quarter to 2.94%. Excluding the impact of excess liquidity, the net interest margin would have been 3.07% in the fourth quarter, an increase of 23 basis points from the third quarter. The increase was primarily a result of lower core deposit rates, maturing higher cost customer CDs and other time deposits and a decrease in excess liquidity. In the fourth quarter, excess liquidity had an approximately 13 basis point negative effect on the margin compared to the 16 basis point impact in the third quarter.Excess liquidity was represented by an average of $2.5 billion deposited with the Federal Reserve in the fourth quarter, down from an average $3.5 billion in the third quarter. With the maturities of wholesale funding and expected loan growth, we expect excess liquidity will dissipate in the first half of the year. This excess liquidity is above and beyond the investment securities portfolio, which will continue to provide a reservoir of liquidity.Turning to Slide 8, we focused on expense management on a daily basis. Our largest expense item is salaries and therefore, management of staff levels is key. As you can see on the slide, we have consistently reduced personnel over the past several years, even while we were opening new banking centers. In 2009, in response to the recession and as part of our ongoing efforts to leverage technology and maximize productivity to support growth, full-time equivalent staff decreased by approximately 850 employees or 8%. In 2010, we expect to achieve a further reduction of about 300 positions or about 3% of the total workforce, which will largely be completed by mid-year. These positions are across all lines of business and geographies. In conjunction with this action, we incurred a severance charge of $11 million in the fourth quarter. Annualized salary savings of about $16 million related to this action are expected going forward. Now Dale Greene, our Chief Credit Officer will discuss credit qualities, starting on Slide 9.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We saw broad-based improvement in our credit metrics in the fourth quarter. As expected, fourth quarter net credit-related charge-offs and the provision for credit losses improved from third quarter levels. Economic conditions continue to be
componenttext: Good morning. We saw broad-based improvement in our credit metrics in the fourth quarter. As expected, fourth quarter net credit-related charge-offs and the provision for credit losses improved from third quarter levels. Economic conditions continue to be challenging, but we are seeing more encouraging signs that things are improving. Net credit-related charge-offs were $225 million in the fourth quarter, a $14 million reduction from the third quarter. Net charge-offs included $62 million in the Commercial Real Estate line of business, primarily related to residential real-estate development, down from $91 million in the third quarter. The decline in Commercial Real Estate charge-offs reflects the wind down of the California local residential real estate portfolio, and the fact we believe we have been taking the necessary charges to reflect declining values over the past two years.We also continue to see value stabilized in select markets. Provision for credit-related losses of $259 million was $54 million less than the third quarter. The provision exceeded net charge-offs by $34 million compared to $74 million in the third quarter, reflecting the improvement in overall credit performance. The allowance for loan losses was 2.34% of total loans, an increase of 15 basis points from the third quarter. The allowance for loan losses was 83% of non-performing loans.Turning to Slide 10, total non-performing assets declined $13 million to $1.3 billion. Importantly, the inflow on non-performing assets decreased by $95 million in the fourth quarter. Loans past due 90 days or more and still accruing declined $60 million to $101 million. Foreclosed property held relatively stable. Other real estate expenses in the fourth quarter increased to $22 million from $10 million in the third quarter. This reflects write-downs related to updated appraisals. The average carrying value of these properties is now well below 40% of the original contractual loan amount.Also we believe that the market is starting to stabilize. Therefore, we expect quarterly ORE [official residence expenses] expenses going forward to be less than the fourth quarter level. Our watch list loans decreased by $520 million to $7.7 billion at the end of the fourth quarter. This reflects improvements in our portfolio in all geographic markets and across virtually all lines of business.On Slide 11, we provided information on the makeup of the non-accrual loans. The largest portion of the non-accrual loans continues to be Commercial Real Estate, which consist primarily of residential real estate development loans. Commercial Real Estate non-accrual loans decreased by $47 million in the quarter. Non-accruals also decreased in Middle-Market by $17 million. Personal Banking, which falls within other business lines, saw a $25 million increase in non-accruals as the weak economy has taken a toll on some of our residential mortgage customers. Because these are primarily seasoned mortgages, the loss content remains low.During the fourth quarter 2009, $266 million of loan relationships, greater than $2 million, were transferred to non-accrual status, a reduction of $95 million from the third quarter. Of these inflows, Commercial Real Estate line of business contributed $64 million, down from $211 million in the third quarter. Middle market at $85 million, a small decrease from the third quarter. Inflows increased modestly in several lines of business, such as Small Business, Global Corporate Banking and Technology and Life Science (sic) [Sciences] from low levels.Slide 12, provides further detail on our non-accrual loans. Collateral values on non-accrual loans are reviewed every quarter as part of our credit-quality review process. We have written down non-performing loans by 44% compared to 34% a year ago. The carrying value, plus the reserve, reflected current market conditions. We had $34 million in total trouble debt restructurings or TDRs. This included $18 million in reduced rate loans, primarily residential mortgages, $5 million in other non-performing TDRs and $11 million in performing TDRs.In the fourth quarter, we sold $11 million in loans, four [ph] loans, totaling $10 million, were non-performing. The average price was close to carrying values plus reserves. We have seen a firming of prices, particularly for distressed syndicated debt. And we continue to pursue loan sales on a one-off basis.On Slide 13, we provide a breakdown of net credit-related charge-offs by office of loan origination. Net charge-offs in all four major geographic markets declined in the fourth quarter. Within the Midwest, which made up 43% of the total, Middle-Market charge-offs declined. Small Business charge-offs were relatively stable, and we saw small increases in private banking and global banking.Western market charge-offs made up 38% of total. The decrease from the third quarter was driven by a decline in residential development-related charge-offs, as well as Global Corporate Banking. Middle market posted an increase from the third quarter.Texas net charge-offs returns were at relatively low level with no particular area of concentration. As far as Florida, net charge-offs declined again in the fourth quarter, as there were no additional significant write-downs on the condo portfolio. Other markets net charge-offs increased with no particular geographic or industry focus.Slide 14, provides detail on net loan charge-offs by line of business. The Commercial Real Estate line of business charge-offs declined, while Middle-Market increased as expected. Charge-offs for Wealth and Institutional Management, Small Business and Personal Banking were relatively stable.On slide 15, we provide a detailed breakdown by geography and project type of our Commercial Real Estate line of business, which declined $194 million from the prior quarter. There is further detail provided in the appendix to these slides. At the December 31, 22% of this portfolio consisted of loans made to residential real estate developers secured by the underlying real estate. Michigan outstandings of $620 million, represented 13% of the portfolio, and were down $142 million from a year ago. Florida outstandings of $553 million represents 11% of the portfolio, and were down $160 million from a year ago.As a shown on Slide 16, as of the end of the fourth quarter, we reduced residential real estate development exposure by $1.2 billion or 54% since June of 2008. Total Single Family construction outstandings were down $785 million or 59% from June 2008. Turning to Slide 17, we displayed project type and geographic breakdown of net charge-offs for the Commercial Real Estate line of business. Consistent with the decline in total Commercial Real Estate non-accrual loans and decline in inflows to non-accrual loans, we had a $29 million or 33% decrease in net charge-offs in the fourth quarter for a total of $62 million. Residential real estate development loan charge-offs decreased by over 50% in the fourth quarter. We have seen prices for Single Family home stabilized and even increase in select markets. However, land prices remain soft and in some locations, continue to decline.Charge-offs in non-Residential Real Estate Construction segment increased in the fourth quarter. The majority can be attributed to a single transaction secured by entitled land in California. While we continue to see softness, we believe that non-residential real estate will see far fewer defaults and much lower loss contest than the Residential Construction segment. In fact, we had only one non-residential Commercial Real Estate loan, over $2 million, transferred to non-accrual in the fourth quarter.Total Commercial Real Estate related charge-offs decreased in Western, Texas and other markets. Midwest was stable. As far as Florida, charge-offs have trended downward for the last two quarters. We have limited land exposure in Florida, and Single Family exposure has been managed down for some time. The issues in Florida are primarily related to condo exposure, which totaled about $100 million at December 31, down from about $125 million at the end of September. Condo closings are occurring, but at a very modest level.Slide 18, provides an overview of our consumer loan portfolio. This portfolio is relatively small, representing less than 10% of our total loans. These loans are self-originated and are part of a full-service relationship. The residential mortgages we hold on our balance sheet are primarily associated with our Private Banking customers. Net charge-offs for residential mortgages decreased again in the fourth quarter. The home equity loan portfolio has held up relatively well with a slight increase in charge-offs in the fourth quarter, and 30- and 90-day delinquency rates improved.Slides detailing our auto dealer and automotive supplies portfolio can be found in the appendix. Both portfolios continue to perform well. As far as the auto supplier portfolio, we continue to reduce our loan outstandings, and it now represents only 2% of our total loans. Non-accrual loans and net charge-offs declined significantly in the fourth quarter. The auto dealer average outstandings have declined $1.4 billion or 32% over the past year, in line with falling sales volumes of new cars. And we continue to have excellent credit quality in this portfolio.To conclude on credit, we conduct in-depth reviews of all of our watch list credits, at least quarterly, to ensure that we have an appropriate workout strategy, as well as reserves and carrying values that reflect our collateral assessments. This proactive action has resulted in a current carrying value of non-performing loans of 56%. We are pleased with the improvement in credit metrics in the fourth quarter. These results, as well as an improving macroeconomic statistics, support our outlook for net credit-related charge-offs of $775 million to $825 million for 2010. We expect the provision for credit losses to slightly exceed net charge-offs for the year. And now, I'll turn the call back to Beth

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dale. Turning to Slide 19, our Tier 1 Capital ratio is well in excess of the well-capitalized thresholds, as defined by the regulators and this has increased in each of the past five quarters.Turning to Slide 20, in the intangible common equity ra
componenttext: Thanks, Dale. Turning to Slide 19, our Tier 1 Capital ratio is well in excess of the well-capitalized thresholds, as defined by the regulators and this has increased in each of the past five quarters.Turning to Slide 20, in the intangible common equity ratio. We had maintained a solid capital structure with a large component of common equity for many years. Our tangible common equity ratio, which was 7.99% at the end of the fourth quarter increased from the third quarter. And historically, has been well above the average ratio of our peer group.Slide 21, provides our expectations for 2010, which is based on a modestly improving economic environment. We expect subdued loan demand for a while longer, as loan growth typically lags other positive economic indicators. We believe we will achieve single-digit period-end-to-period-end loan growth. We expect the securities' portfolio will remain at the current level.Based on the assumption that there will not be an increase in the Fed funds rates in 2010, we expect that net interest margin will increase to 3.15% to 3.25% as a result of maturities of higher cost CDs and wholesale funding, and a reduction in excess liquidity. In addition, we expect the margin will continue to benefit from the improved loan pricing.  Our outlook is for net credit-related charge-offs of $775 million to $825 million. Provision is expected to be slightly in excess of net charge-offs. Non-interest income, excluding 2009 securities gains, is expected to be flat as increases in core fee income are offset by 2009 non-recurring item, such as gains on the repurchase of debt.The expected reduction of pension, FDIC and ORE expense, as well as the continued careful control of discretionary cost is expected to result in low single-digit decrease in expenses. Overall, the many positive signs we saw in the fourth quarter, such as improved credit metrics, continued strong deposit growth, a slower pace of decline in loan demand and a significant increase in the net interest margin lead us to believe that we will continue to see improvement in our core operating fundamentals in 2010. Now we'd be happy to answer any questions you may have.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to start, maybe to drill down into the provision guidance a bit, I believe its full year provision exceeding net charge-offs, but Dale do you expect in the later quarters of 2010 to actually start providing below net charge-offs?
componenttext: Just to start, maybe to drill down into the provision guidance a bit, I believe its full year provision exceeding net charge-offs, but Dale do you expect in the later quarters of 2010 to actually start providing below net charge-offs?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve. My sense of it is that with the very broad-based improvement in the metrics we saw in the fourth quarter and there was just a number of them that we talked about, that we should continue to see that delta -- you saw the reduction actually betw
componenttext: Yes, Steve. My sense of it is that with the very broad-based improvement in the metrics we saw in the fourth quarter and there was just a number of them that we talked about, that we should continue to see that delta -- you saw the reduction actually between the charge-offs and provision fall rather substantially from quarter to quarter, last quarter. So my guess is that we continue to see the economy show steady improvement that we'd probably be at that point.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow-up on that, given what we saw with the watch list this quarter, how should we think about the trend and inflows into non-accrual?  Should that just gap down here and do you expect it to be more gradual through the year?
componenttext: And then just a follow-up on that, given what we saw with the watch list this quarter, how should we think about the trend and inflows into non-accrual?  Should that just gap down here and do you expect it to be more gradual through the year?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't suspect that it will be like falling off a cliff. But I do think that we will, in fact, see gradual improvement as the economy continues to improve. And clearly, everything we're seeing kind of points to that. So hopefully, that is in fact the cas
componenttext: I don't suspect that it will be like falling off a cliff. But I do think that we will, in fact, see gradual improvement as the economy continues to improve. And clearly, everything we're seeing kind of points to that. So hopefully, that is in fact the case.

componenttext: And just one technical one for -- about the guidance for the single-digit decrease in non-interest expense, is that off the base of the $1.649 billion?

componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, we just want to give a little push back on the guidance for loan growth of mid single-digit point-to-point in 2010. We know there's a historical correlation between the inflection point [ph] economic growth, which happened this year and loan growth
componenttext: First, we just want to give a little push back on the guidance for loan growth of mid single-digit point-to-point in 2010. We know there's a historical correlation between the inflection point [ph] economic growth, which happened this year and loan growth recovery next year, but given that your loans are still shrinking at a pretty rapid pace, and this recession is deeper and longer than most, how can you make us feel a little more comfortable about positive loan growth next year or actually this year 2010?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The guidance was for low single-digit growth from the period in , so 12/31/09 to 12/31/10. And when you look at, well, how we're thinking of it, it will be pretty muted, if you think about loans in the first half of this year, and we'll see more rise towa
componenttext: The guidance was for low single-digit growth from the period in , so 12/31/09 to 12/31/10. And when you look at, well, how we're thinking of it, it will be pretty muted, if you think about loans in the first half of this year, and we'll see more rise toward the end of this year. And so we're expecting  expecting a fairly typical pattern, which is probably two to three quarters after GDP turns positive, we start as an industry seeing C&I loans. So we believe that could start towards the end of the second quarter in the second quarter and then perhaps pick up pace, that's our expectation in the second half. So this, we're talking low single-digit, period-end to period-end growth. So it really muted in the first half with more growth in the second. And I think the other point is we were pleased that while loans were down in the fourth quarter, that they were down at a slower pace than they were in the third. So that's at least progress towards what I just described.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is there any that you can point to quantitatively or fundamentally, that you're seeing a turn with your clients or demanded for C&I loans as you can point to that makes us see that it turns coming?
componenttext: And is there any that you can point to quantitatively or fundamentally, that you're seeing a turn with your clients or demanded for C&I loans as you can point to that makes us see that it turns coming?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing is -- we're starting to see some good activity. We're starting to see some backlogs grow. Clients are starting to talk a little bit more optimistically. So we're starting to hear the things. We're starting to see the things that
componenttext: I think what we're seeing is -- we're starting to see some good activity. We're starting to see some backlogs grow. Clients are starting to talk a little bit more optimistically. So we're starting to hear the things. We're starting to see the things that would suggest that our loan volumes should start to improve. I don't suspect that you'll necessary, as Beth indicated, see that as much earlier in the year as later in the year. The other issue is, as you know, we've had a reasonably sized [ph] dealer book that's come down quite a bit because of sales volumes. Sales are rebounding nicely. Dealer inventories are at very low levels. So I think we're going to start to see that business grow a bit as well, not only with existing clients, but obviously with the new clients.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And clearly, in the lines, we're seeing new lines as well as renewed lines that are supporting what Dale and Beth said. The customers are getting prepared and feeling a little more positive about what's going on. And they want to be in the position to sei
componenttext: And clearly, in the lines, we're seeing new lines as well as renewed lines that are supporting what Dale and Beth said. The customers are getting prepared and feeling a little more positive about what's going on. And they want to be in the position to seize the opportunity as it moves forward.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Rochester with FBR.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Rochester with FBR.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you qualify a little bit more where the pipeline is building, which products and the geographies?
componenttext: Can you qualify a little bit more where the pipeline is building, which products and the geographies?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly middle market and particularly in Texas and California, we're seeing good activities. We're seeing some opportunities, certainly in large corporate space, particularly Texas, where obviously, we've been now headquartered for the last couple
componenttext: Well, clearly middle market and particularly in Texas and California, we're seeing good activities. We're seeing some opportunities, certainly in large corporate space, particularly Texas, where obviously, we've been now headquartered for the last couple of years. But I'd say, it's fairly broad-based. As I said, the dealer book, I think we're going to start to seeing some activity there as dealers build inventory. And as you know, that's been a very good business for us through the years. And clearly, with the banking centers we've got, with more of a focus on the small business side, we would hope to see more small business grow.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So at this point, not really seeing on the small business side, more in the middle market side?
componenttext: So at this point, not really seeing on the small business side, more in the middle market side?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, more middle market, but I think we're also starting to see in some other areas as well. And clearly, our focus, as we said for a long time, we're kind of really more in the middle market space. We like that space. We have great opportunities given o
componenttext: Well, more middle market, but I think we're also starting to see in some other areas as well. And clearly, our focus, as we said for a long time, we're kind of really more in the middle market space. We like that space. We have great opportunities given our market share. And Texas and California, I think there's tremendous upside with the kind of banking we do and the model we bring to the table.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Generally, at what percentage of loans are sitting on floor at this point, and what percentage of the book has been renewed at those higher spreads?
componenttext: Generally, at what percentage of loans are sitting on floor at this point, and what percentage of the book has been renewed at those higher spreads?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So two questions, one is about floors. It's only about $3 billion of our $42 billion loan book that has floors, so it's not a significant impact. The second is on the repricing. I think, as we get into the balance of this year, that we will have effective
componenttext: So two questions, one is about floors. It's only about $3 billion of our $42 billion loan book that has floors, so it's not a significant impact. The second is on the repricing. I think, as we get into the balance of this year, that we will have effectively repriced the entire loan portfolio. And we saw a good improvement in loan spreads in '09 and part of our margin guidance improvement in 2010 entails further working through the portfolio of repricing. So that we'll see further along spread expansion this year as well.

componenttext: I guess I'll take the other side of the loan growth argument. And I think when it comes back, it will probably come back, both sooner and a little bit more unexpected. But the tricky thing to figure out is who's in the position to get this growth? And we can see that you have the mix that would suggest that you should get it. But are there any metrics that you could provide that suggests you've maintained or gained market share in terms of sales staff or increasing credit commitments?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: As we have focused on the current environment, and as you know, moving our headquarters a couple of years ago down to Texas, the focus has been in the fast-growing markets for us, which are both Texas and California. Today, we believe we have capacity in California, and we're continuing to look at where we are here, and how we want to move forward with the resources necessary to be prepared for the term. That's part of the overall strategy and was when we moved here even before the downturn of the economy.

componenttext: Dale, quick question on the C&I. I know that migration in this product is notoriously lumpy. What are you thinking in terms of your key clauses and NPLs? Have we seen it? Is it this quarter? Or do you expect some further deterioration as we move through 2010?

componenttext: I think, again, if you look, Heather at any metric you want and put them all together, I think, not only have we said we thought the fourth quarter would show improvements, and certainly, we said it would see improvements in charge-offs. But across the board, we've seen just steady improvements. And when I look at the Watch category down $520 million quarter-over-quarter, and I look at the components of it. I feel pretty good that in the C&I book, that we're not only are we on top of it but we should see steady improvements. I'm very confident in that. And so that book has held up well for us.

componenttextpreview: Question for you, Dale, maybe it's obvious, but maybe not. In terms of the low rate environment, how much is in credit for your company and many others looks like it has peaked or is on a verge of peaking. How important was zero rate interest policy from
componenttext: Question for you, Dale, maybe it's obvious, but maybe not. In terms of the low rate environment, how much is in credit for your company and many others looks like it has peaked or is on a verge of peaking. How important was zero rate interest policy from the Fed in terms of borrowers getting over the hump? And then secondly, consensus is pre-limited right now, it's late this year and ended 2011, but if rates go up, say 300 bps, does that matter for credit in 2011?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Typically, in the real estate side, Single Family, in particular that a lot of the programs and the rates are or one of piece have certainly helped. I don't think there's any question.
componenttext: Typically, in the real estate side, Single Family, in particular that a lot of the programs and the rates are or one of piece have certainly helped. I don't think there's any question.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: How about C&I?
componenttext: How about C&I?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In C&I, I think, in general, that has been probably less of an issue than it has been for real estate. I wouldn't discount it as not being important. But I think, its a little less significant in the C&I book than for the real estate book for us. As to a
componenttext: In C&I, I think, in general, that has been probably less of an issue than it has been for real estate. I wouldn't discount it as not being important. But I think, its a little less significant in the C&I book than for the real estate book for us. As to a rate hike and its impact, it's hard to evaluate, I think people are probably at some point will anticipate that, that their plans are going to incorporate that. I think as the economy gets better, most of our customers have rationalized the devil out of their expense structure. They've lived with an environment and whether it be in Michigan or anywhere else, for two or more years of difficulty. So I think the employees will take advantage of revenue growth. I think we will see revenue growth, and I think that will help accommodate whatever happens on the rate side.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I think, Jeff, as rates are growing up as much as you're just describing that. Hopefully, that means there's a good strong oath underlying, that which will be helpful to what you just described. And in addition, obviously a rate rise often helps us fr
componenttext: And I think, Jeff, as rates are growing up as much as you're just describing that. Hopefully, that means there's a good strong oath underlying, that which will be helpful to what you just described. And in addition, obviously a rate rise often helps us from an interest rate liability standpoint. So I think rising rates probably means a better economy, which is good news for Comerica and our customers.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: Well, we continue to monitor what's available. And as we've said many times in the past, the key for us is it has to fit our model in our markets, and we're very careful as we evaluate that. We're looking at them to fit into our longer term strategy, not as a transaction in the short-term.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question, [indiscernible] showed a little bit of loans this quarter, $10 million or so. I was wondering if you're seeing any incremental opportunities for loan sales? How that's market acting? And whether or not that would fit your strategy to conti
componenttext: First question, [indiscernible] showed a little bit of loans this quarter, $10 million or so. I was wondering if you're seeing any incremental opportunities for loan sales? How that's market acting? And whether or not that would fit your strategy to continue to manage the loss content.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, and it looks good. I would have to say that, and particularly as we indicated on sort of more of the syndicated side, clearly, the secondary market is looking better. We always are evaluating opportunities. But across the board, I would say ther
componenttext: Yes, yes, and it looks good. I would have to say that, and particularly as we indicated on sort of more of the syndicated side, clearly, the secondary market is looking better. We always are evaluating opportunities. But across the board, I would say there's more interest in distressed asset sales, whether it's packages of deals or one off deals. I think in a lot of cases, let's say it's real estate, the prices of real estate and the write-downs have been so significant to people are now starting to say maybe the bottom has been reached or maybe we're on the upside of that, depending on the market, very, very good activity. We continue to look at that as one of our strategies to shed assets, certainly, problem assets. And we'll continue to do that.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a little color on two more items. First of all, I noticed that there's no provide for Florida this quarter. Just wondering how confident you are maybe that you're really kind of pass the peak in Florida? And then secondly, if you could j
componenttext: Could you give us a little color on two more items. First of all, I noticed that there's no provide for Florida this quarter. Just wondering how confident you are maybe that you're really kind of pass the peak in Florida? And then secondly, if you could just kind of drill down a little bit onto this income-producing CRE? And just give little bit more color about why you're continuing to feel so confident about that part of the book?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Florida, in terms of the real estate side is only $500 million. For us, condos were the issue, that's down to $100 million. We've taken the marks there that I think we need to take. Condos are selling although at lower prices and lower absorptions but the
componenttext: Florida, in terms of the real estate side is only $500 million. For us, condos were the issue, that's down to $100 million. We've taken the marks there that I think we need to take. Condos are selling although at lower prices and lower absorptions but they are selling. That market is actually starting -- depending which part of who are you talking about. And I think we're not -- we're in the market and we're not going to be in there. We think they're coming back nicely. So we feel pretty good about what we're seeing there, seeing very good about the marks we've already taken. So that's why Florida, we're feeling very good about at this point. Across the board, income-producing properties for us, again a lot of our construction loans have reached completion or nearing completion. So again, the construction piece is behind us. We're seeing in many cases that the discounted cash flows are sufficient to structure deals into a mini-perm. We have numerous examples of deals that we've done that with. And not only are we able to structure into mini-perms, we're able to get, in many cases more collateral, cross-collateralized. We're also usually able to get better rates and other structure enhancements. So it's a good opportunity right now for us as loans are completed to really strengthen our position, and that's what we've done.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to reinforce Dale and his script. He's indicated that we only had one non-potential Commercial Real Estate loan over $2 million transferred to non-accrual in fourth quarter. So there's not a big pile that's waiting to come in or has come in. So that's
componenttext: And to reinforce Dale and his script. He's indicated that we only had one non-potential Commercial Real Estate loan over $2 million transferred to non-accrual in fourth quarter. So there's not a big pile that's waiting to come in or has come in. So that's a good indicator as well.

componenttext: If I think about your deposits and how this loan growth issue's going to play out, should we expect a quarter at some point down the road where DDAs shrink, loans aren't growing at, but that's actually somewhat a bullish sign because that's the first sorts of corporates actually investing. They draw down on their own cash?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that would be exactly what you'll see because people are keeping their liquidity and they've got it in deposits. They're waiting for the turn. They will spend that before they begin to draw down on their lines.
componenttext: I think that would be exactly what you'll see because people are keeping their liquidity and they've got it in deposits. They're waiting for the turn. They will spend that before they begin to draw down on their lines.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: And then so the follow-up will be, if I look at your Slide 6, people don't raise their hand and define their deposits as excess liquidity versus market share, but do you have a sense of how much your deposit growth over the past year especially, has been market share gains versus excess liquidity from your customers?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's been a blend, again, back to the mix of our business being in, even though we kind of the downturn being in a couple of the high-growth markets has been a plus there. And as I mentioned earlier, people are being very cautious, including picking up ne
componenttext: It's been a blend, again, back to the mix of our business being in, even though we kind of the downturn being in a couple of the high-growth markets has been a plus there. And as I mentioned earlier, people are being very cautious, including picking up new customers. But I don't have a number on the exact mix of that.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the slide you referred to Brian, Slide 6, you can see we've been growing DDA actually for -- our chart goes back the fourth quarter of '07. But as you can see, through this recession and that liquidity you talked about in acceleration of that growth. S
componenttext: On the slide you referred to Brian, Slide 6, you can see we've been growing DDA actually for -- our chart goes back the fourth quarter of '07. But as you can see, through this recession and that liquidity you talked about in acceleration of that growth. So we have been growing DDA, it's just been growing faster with the environment that we just described.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: When we think about your capital ratios, TCs, best-in-class, risk-weighted assets work against-ed you, so the Tier 1 common, Tier 1 x TARP, they're all good but not at the top of the stack. Do you feel like you get credit for that when you speak with the
componenttext: When we think about your capital ratios, TCs, best-in-class, risk-weighted assets work against-ed you, so the Tier 1 common, Tier 1 x TARP, they're all good but not at the top of the stack. Do you feel like you get credit for that when you speak with the constituents you're dealing with especially around the TARP issue? I guess your risk ratings are high, but your charge-offs and NPA trends would as I guess a necessarily is a riskier balance sheet?

componenttextpreview: I think it's well understood, and everybody understands where we are. And that's the reason our bent is to [ph] as Beth indicated in her comments, to a solid and a strong capital base and being at the 7.99% on the equity side.
componenttext: I think it's well understood, and everybody understands where we are. And that's the reason our bent is to [ph] as Beth indicated in her comments, to a solid and a strong capital base and being at the 7.99% on the equity side.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Klock with KBW.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: By now, just about every one of my questions has been answered. The Commercial Real Estate portfolio, the income-producing piece, how much of that comes up for renewal in 2010, that maybe you could be concerned with about collateral values on those proper
componenttext: By now, just about every one of my questions has been answered. The Commercial Real Estate portfolio, the income-producing piece, how much of that comes up for renewal in 2010, that maybe you could be concerned with about collateral values on those properties that come up for renewal this year?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can't tell you exactly when we come up for renewal this year. But again, since we haven't really made a new construction loan in a couple two and a half, maybe three years. And we typically make them for two to three years. A lot of them have already co
componenttext: I can't tell you exactly when we come up for renewal this year. But again, since we haven't really made a new construction loan in a couple two and a half, maybe three years. And we typically make them for two to three years. A lot of them have already come up for renewal and we dealt with them. As it relates to valuations, we're doing valuations all the time. So I'm not particularly concerned about valuations having a necessarily a big impact on us, because we're going to those as you know. But for the most part, we're seeing generally just improvements in the Commercial Real Estate space, particularly income-producing. We're seeing projects that are leasing up nicely, obviously, in those cases, whether or not we're dealing with them. So I'm not really overly concerned about it Brian, because I think because of the way, the fact that we haven't made into one in sometime, a lot of them we already dealt with. And there's not that many more that we have to face this year.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Beth, in the fourth quarter, the tax rate -- the credit defective tax rate was a little bit higher than I thought. But was there any thing one-time in there or anything that drove that? Or is it still related to the BOLI [bank-owned Life Insuranc
componenttext: And then Beth, in the fourth quarter, the tax rate -- the credit defective tax rate was a little bit higher than I thought. But was there any thing one-time in there or anything that drove that? Or is it still related to the BOLI [bank-owned Life Insurance] [ph] and the  other low income housing credits at the adjustments there?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are no unusual tax items in the fourth quarter. In the second and third, we did have some settlements and some interest in tax refunds. But there's nothing unusual in the fourth quarter. And I think the guidance we gave, it certainly for 2010, is th
componenttext: There are no unusual tax items in the fourth quarter. In the second and third, we did have some settlements and some interest in tax refunds. But there's nothing unusual in the fourth quarter. And I think the guidance we gave, it certainly for 2010, is the -- on how the tax is calculated, it's consistent with what we've been saying.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Rose with Raymond James.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That portfolio has performed nicely for us. As you know, we're moving more and more to relationships and less transactions. In terms of the credit metrics, they're a slightly improved where they were in the last quarter. And you saw the results of our SNI
componenttext: That portfolio has performed nicely for us. As you know, we're moving more and more to relationships and less transactions. In terms of the credit metrics, they're a slightly improved where they were in the last quarter. And you saw the results of our SNIK portfolio as it relates to the SNIK exam, but pretty much all are reflected in the third quarter,  and its granular it's across a number of lines of business and so forth.  My comments in the SNIK portfolio is it's a piece of our business that we want to develop further the relationships. And I think all in is performing very satisfactorily.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And secondarily, can you talk about your energy portfolio in general? And kind of any demand improvement that you might see over the coming year?
componenttext: And secondarily, can you talk about your energy portfolio in general? And kind of any demand improvement that you might see over the coming year?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again the energy book as I think performed very well for us. We are very active in terms of how we manage the price stack. We meet monthly on that, and reset it as appropriate. We're more focused on gas than we would be on oil. Energy prices have come bac
componenttext: Again the energy book as I think performed very well for us. We are very active in terms of how we manage the price stack. We meet monthly on that, and reset it as appropriate. We're more focused on gas than we would be on oil. Energy prices have come back nicely. We have opportunities there to do more business. I think as the capital markets continue to improve, a lot of the credits that we provide financing for will find opportunities to go to the capital markets, which was always their intent. It's been a very good book. We're not at the low end, we're not in the high end. We're very focused on kind of the mid cap types of companies, that I think are very strong but solid properties behind them.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And last question will come from the line of Gary Tenner with Soleil Securities.
componenttext: And last question will come from the line of Gary Tenner with Soleil Securities.

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dale, I just have a question for you regarding the outlook in terms of the charge-off and provide trends for 2010. Given the trends we saw in the fourth quarter, which are pretty universally positive for you, the way that the current NPAs are marked,  I s
componenttext: Dale, I just have a question for you regarding the outlook in terms of the charge-off and provide trends for 2010. Given the trends we saw in the fourth quarter, which are pretty universally positive for you, the way that the current NPAs are marked,  I still find it a little surprising that you'd expect to end 2010 with kind of flat to higher loan loss reserve as compared to this year. I'm wondering if you could give more of an outlook in terms of why you expect to be heading to 2011 given the trends you have right now with the reserves?

headline: Comerica Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think if you look at the fourth quarter, you see that the provision as compared to the charge-offs was about $34 million or so over the charge-offs, down substantially from where it's been. If you look at each quarter throughout 2009, you would hav
componenttext: Well I think if you look at the fourth quarter, you see that the provision as compared to the charge-offs was about $34 million or so over the charge-offs, down substantially from where it's been. If you look at each quarter throughout 2009, you would have seen charge-offs a little lighter in the first half of the year, heavier in the second half which is clearly how we built the provision. I believe that given our outlook for charge-offs, and I think we have the question earlier that we should probably continue to see the first half provision continue to be in excess of charge-offs but at the declining rate. And I believe that we are very likely to see provision in the second half of the year to be below charge-offs simply because I think we will continue to see improving credit metrics. I believe the broad-based improvement we saw in the fourth quarter will largely continue throughout all of this year. And obviously, we look at each quarter as we always do to see where we are. And if we've seen the kind of improvements we've seen in the fourth quarter, we'll adjust.
